Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do we hiccup?
Options: A. Our diaphragm causes our vocal folds to involuntarily spasm causing a hiccup., B. Our lungs involuntarily spasm and cause the diaphragm to clamp down., C. Our diaphragm has an involuntary spasm which causes us to take in a sudden gulp of air and our vocal folds clamp shut., D. Our vocal folds involuntarily spasm and cause our lungs to seize and our diaphragm to clamp down.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary muscle responsible for hiccups? Options: A. The diaphragm, B. The vocal folds, C. The vagus nerve, D. The lungs Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the result of a hiccup? Options: A. A sudden contraction of the diaphragm, B. A sudden relaxation of the diaphragm, C. A sudden increase in breathing rate, D. A sudden decrease in breathing rate Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of the vagus nerve? Options: A. To regulate breathing and heartbeat, B. To regulate digestion and metabolism, C. To regulate blood pressure and body temperature, D. To regulate muscle movement and reflexes Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the effect of gulping down a teaspoon of sugar on the vagus nerve? Options: A. It increases the activity of the vagus nerve, B. It decreases the activity of the vagus nerve, C. It distracts the vagus nerve from the diaphragm, D. It has no effect on the vagus nerve Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary reason behind most hiccup-busting techniques? Options: A. To increase the level of oxygen in the bloodstream, B. To decrease the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, C. To increase the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, D. To decrease the level of oxygen in the bloodstream Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the effect of holding one's breath on the internal CO2 concentration? Options: A. It decreases the internal CO2 concentration, B. It increases the internal CO2 concentration, C. It has no effect on the internal CO2 concentration, D. It decreases the oxygen concentration Correct Option: None
Question 7: According to the SciShow Survey, what percentage of respondents preferred holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 37%, B. 54%, C. 67%, D. 80% Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary function of the diaphragm? Options: A. To regulate breathing and heartbeat, B. To regulate digestion and metabolism, C. To regulate blood pressure and body temperature, D. To facilitate breathing and oxygen intake Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the result of a hiccup on the vocal folds? Options: A. They contract suddenly, B. They relax suddenly, C. They remain unchanged, D. They become paralyzed Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the primary reason behind the human body's fascination with hiccup cures? Options: A. The complexity of the human body, B. The weirdness of the human body, C. The simplicity of the human body, D. The lack of understanding of the human body Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: What is the result of a hiccup? Options: A. A sudden contraction of the diaphragm, B. A sudden relaxation of the diaphragm, C. A sudden increase in breathing rate, D. A sudden decrease in breathing rate.

However, the correct answer is not explicitly stated in the options provided for Question 2. A more accurate representation of the ground truth MCQ would be a combination of the content in Question 2 and the correct answer choice from the ground truth MCQ.

A closer examination of the generated MCQs reveals that none of them perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Nevertheless, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ, I would select Question 2, with the understanding that the correct answer choice is not accurately represented.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a diaphragm?
Options: A. A small muscle in between your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing., B. A sac of air pockets that live inside your lung and are most important for breathing., C. A nerve that runs from the base of your skull down your spine and is important for breathing., D. A sheet of muscle underneath your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing.
Correct Option: D

Question 3: What is the primary function of the vagus nerve? Options: A. To regulate breathing and heartbeat, B. To regulate digestion and metabolism, C. To regulate blood pressure and body temperature, D. To regulate muscle movement and reflexes Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the effect of gulping down a teaspoon of sugar on the vagus nerve? Options: A. It increases the activity of the vagus nerve, B. It decreases the activity of the vagus nerve, C. It distracts the vagus nerve from the diaphragm, D. It has no effect on the vagus nerve Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary reason behind most hiccup-busting techniques? Options: A. To increase the level of oxygen in the bloodstream, B. To decrease the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, C. To increase the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, D. To decrease the level of oxygen in the bloodstream Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the effect of holding one's breath on the internal CO2 concentration? Options: A. It decreases the internal CO2 concentration, B. It increases the internal CO2 concentration, C. It has no effect on the internal CO2 concentration, D. It decreases the oxygen concentration Correct Option: None
Question 7: According to the SciShow Survey, what percentage of respondents preferred holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 37%, B. 54%, C. 67%, D. 80% Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary function of the diaphragm? Options: A. To regulate breathing and heartbeat, B. To regulate digestion and metabolism, C. To regulate blood pressure and body temperature, D. To facilitate breathing and oxygen intake Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the result of a hiccup on the vocal folds? Options: A. They contract suddenly, B. They relax suddenly, C. They remain unchanged, D. They become paralyzed Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the primary reason behind the human body's fascination with hiccup cures? Options: A. The complexity of the human body, B. The weirdness of the human body, C. The simplicity of the human body, D. The lack of understanding of the human body Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

However, the options provided for Question 8 do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. A closer examination of the generated MCQs reveals that none of them perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. Nevertheless, Question 8 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do we stop hiccups?
Options: A. We have to tell our diaphragm to stop hiccupping., B. We have to hit the reset button on our nervous system and get our diaphragm to relax., C. We have to stimulate our diaphragm more to make it change the hiccups., D. We can't stop hiccups, they stop themselves.
Correct Option: B

Question 2: What is the result of a hiccup? Options: A. A sudden contraction of the diaphragm, B. A sudden relaxation of the diaphragm, C. A sudden increase in breathing rate, D. A sudden decrease in breathing rate Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of the vagus nerve? Options: A. To regulate breathing and heartbeat, B. To regulate digestion and metabolism, C. To regulate blood pressure and body temperature, D. To regulate muscle movement and reflexes Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the effect of gulping down a teaspoon of sugar on the vagus nerve? Options: A. It increases the activity of the vagus nerve, B. It decreases the activity of the vagus nerve, C. It distracts the vagus nerve from the diaphragm, D. It has no effect on the vagus nerve Correct Option: None

Question 6: What is the effect of holding one's breath on the internal CO2 concentration? Options: A. It decreases the internal CO2 concentration, B. It increases the internal CO2 concentration, C. It has no effect on the internal CO2 concentration, D. It decreases the oxygen concentration Correct Option: None
Question 7: According to the SciShow Survey, what percentage of respondents preferred holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 37%, B. 54%, C. 67%, D. 80% Correct Option: None

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, based on the information provided in the transcript, the closest match can be determined by analyzing the content.

The ground truth MCQ asks, "How do we stop hiccups?" with the correct option being "We have to hit the reset button on our nervous system and get our diaphragm to relax." This question is focused on the solution to stopping hiccups.

Among the generated MCQs, Question 5 is the closest match in terms of content. It asks, "What is the primary reason behind most hiccup-busting techniques?" with options related to the level of carbon dioxide or oxygen in the bloodstream. Although it does not directly ask how to stop hiccups, it is related to the solution.

However, another generated MCQ, Question 6, is also related to the solution, as it asks about the effect of holding one's breath on the internal CO2 concentration, which is a technique mentioned in the transcript for stopping hiccups.

But the best match is actually not present among the generated MCQs as they are not directly addressing the question of "how" but rather "what" and "why". Still, among the provided options, Question 5 is the closest one.

So the index of the most similar generated MCQ would be: 5

Matching Prompt:

There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing

diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly

means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does swallowing a spoonful of sugar help stop hiccups?
Options: A. Swallowing sugar is hard. It confuses the Vagus Nerve and makes it start concentrating on your throat swallowing which leave the diaphragm alone., B. Swallowing sugar is too sweet. It refocuses the Vagus Nerve on the incredible sweetness which leaves the diaphragm alone., C. Swallowing sugar stimulates your vocal folds and causes them to relax., D. Swallowing sugar causes your body to inhale a large amount of oxygen which calms your diaphragm.
Correct Option: A

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks how swallowing a spoonful of sugar helps stop hiccups. The correct option for Question 4, "It distracts the vagus nerve from the diaphragm," is similar to the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, "Swallowing sugar is hard. It confuses the Vagus Nerve and makes it start concentrating on your throat swallowing which leave the diaphragm alone."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] Hey there, engineer buddies! I just want to thank you so much
for helping out in the last episode. I needed to get my phone out of the storm
drain, and together, we designed a solution. Our robot was just one of many possible solutions, and maybe you had an even better idea at home. If you did, please send it my way.
I'd love to check it out! But I've got a whole new challenge for you. Have you ever just wanted
some space to yourself? A place to relax, do your own thing,
eat Nutella straight off your fingers, and burp with abandon? Yeah, I need that.
That is a thing I need. You know what can help? I bet you already guessed it! Engineering. So how do we use the engineering
process to solve this problem? [Music] Well, first, we've got to define the problem. I need a place that is secluded and quiet. I need it to provide privacy
and a sense of my-ownness. Sounds pretty great, right? What about a big box to use as my space? It's secluded and it can be all my own. Solution-wise, it's a start, but a small one. We need to consider more options. What if I made adjustments to a
space I already have: my room? I could hang blankets from the ceiling
to help block out sounds from outside, and then I could also sing my
head off to T Swift if I wanted to without bothering the rest of my family. To top things off, I could add
a "Do Not Enter" sign to my door. Like, a serious sign. 
Bold font, all caps. Respect my sign! Okay, we've got two options. What else? What if instead of adjusting a space
I already have, I create a new space? There's a word for what we're
talking about here: architecture. Maybe we could become not just engineers,
but architects: engineers who design buildings. Even though the title of the job is a little
different, the process is still the same. So before doing architecture, we've got to weigh our options and choose
the best design to take into trials. Let's think about the box idea first. It's probably too small. I'd either be squished or
be half hanging out of it. Okay, how about tricking out my room? Again, while I'd feel like I have a sense
of privacy, I'd know that at any point, any one of my family members could bust in, and the blankets on the walls 
would muffle some of the sound, but wouldn't totally block them out. But hey, here's an idea:
what about a tree house? It would be totally my own, it would be far enough from my house that any weird burps or loud renditions
of "Shake It Off" wouldn't bug my family. Of course, it would take some
work. Some architecture work. So architect, activate!  [Music] Let's build the treehouse! It'll have a drop-down rope ladder that
I can pull up for optimal privacy, and it'll have windows so I can spot
when someone's on the way over and properly prepare myself. I can even use the blanket wall idea from
my second proposal to muffle the sound. Of course, I'll need space for lounging
and reading and dancing around, but before we start building,
you know what we've got to do? Build the prototype and test it. And in order to conduct useful trials,
we need to isolate the variables. What are the variables of
this particular mission? The size of the treehouse we choose
and the weight of the treehouse are really important variables
because we gotta make sure the treehouse can stay in the tree. What about variables when it comes
to soundproofing the thing? The number and the size of the
blankets that I use would be one, and so would be the amount of noise
I plan on making inside the treehouse. And we have to keep in
mind failure points, too. Like, the tree might be able to support
little old me in a small wooden tree house, but if I have a friend or two over,
the load might be too heavy. That would be a serious failure point. As for keeping things nice and quiet,
maybe my thickest heaviest blankets can block a soft rendition
of "You Belong With Me," but they might fail when I belt out
"Shake It Off" or have a burping contest. You've gotta test these things! So we'll keep working with the variables
until we've got a working design. Then, it's time to build. [Music] Architects use the same process,
the engineering process, when planning buildings from
skyscrapers to small family homes. I came up with what I think
will be a great treehouse, but as always, there can be lots
of different successful solutions. So here's your challenge: can you come
up with your own architecture solution? What would your building look like? How would it meet the success
criteria and navigate the variables? Let us know! [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the video, we see that one failure point is if she builds a treehouse, she may be able to stay in but can't have friends over. What is a failure point?
Options: A. A place where a solution to a problem fails., B. A place where a solution to a problem has limits., C. A place where a solution to a problem causes a collapse in the solution., D. A place where a solution to the problem causes another unknown variable.
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] Hey there, engineer buddies! I just want to thank you so much
for helping out in the last episode. I needed to get my phone out of the storm
drain, and together, we designed a solution. Our robot was just one of many possible solutions, and maybe you had an even better idea at home. If you did, please send it my way.
I'd love to check it out! But I've got a whole new challenge for you. Have you ever just wanted
some space to yourself? A place to relax, do your own thing,
eat Nutella straight off your fingers, and burp with abandon? Yeah, I need that.
That is a thing I need. You know what can help? I bet you already guessed it! Engineering. So how do we use the engineering
process to solve this problem? [Music] Well, first, we've got to define the problem. I need a place that is secluded and quiet. I need it to provide privacy
and a sense of my-ownness. Sounds pretty great, right? What about a big box to use as my space? It's secluded and it can be all my own. Solution-wise, it's a start, but a small one. We need to consider more options. What if I made adjustments to a
space I already have: my room? I could hang blankets from the ceiling
to help block out sounds from outside, and then I could also sing my
head off to T Swift if I wanted to without bothering the rest of my family. To top things off, I could add
a "Do Not Enter" sign to my door. Like, a serious sign. 
Bold font, all caps. Respect my sign! Okay, we've got two options. What else? What if instead of adjusting a space
I already have, I create a new space? There's a word for what we're
talking about here: architecture. Maybe we could become not just engineers,
but architects: engineers who design buildings. Even though the title of the job is a little
different, the process is still the same. So before doing architecture, we've got to weigh our options and choose
the best design to take into trials. Let's think about the box idea first. It's probably too small. I'd either be squished or
be half hanging out of it. Okay, how about tricking out my room? Again, while I'd feel like I have a sense
of privacy, I'd know that at any point, any one of my family members could bust in, and the blankets on the walls 
would muffle some of the sound, but wouldn't totally block them out. But hey, here's an idea:
what about a tree house? It would be totally my own, it would be far enough from my house that any weird burps or loud renditions
of "Shake It Off" wouldn't bug my family. Of course, it would take some
work. Some architecture work. So architect, activate!  [Music] Let's build the treehouse! It'll have a drop-down rope ladder that
I can pull up for optimal privacy, and it'll have windows so I can spot
when someone's on the way over and properly prepare myself. I can even use the blanket wall idea from
my second proposal to muffle the sound. Of course, I'll need space for lounging
and reading and dancing around, but before we start building,
you know what we've got to do? Build the prototype and test it. And in order to conduct useful trials,
we need to isolate the variables. What are the variables of
this particular mission? The size of the treehouse we choose
and the weight of the treehouse are really important variables
because we gotta make sure the treehouse can stay in the tree. What about variables when it comes
to soundproofing the thing? The number and the size of the
blankets that I use would be one, and so would be the amount of noise
I plan on making inside the treehouse. And we have to keep in
mind failure points, too. Like, the tree might be able to support
little old me in a small wooden tree house, but if I have a friend or two over,
the load might be too heavy. That would be a serious failure point. As for keeping things nice and quiet,
maybe my thickest heaviest blankets can block a soft rendition
of "You Belong With Me," but they might fail when I belt out
"Shake It Off" or have a burping contest. You've gotta test these things! So we'll keep working with the variables
until we've got a working design. Then, it's time to build. [Music] Architects use the same process,
the engineering process, when planning buildings from
skyscrapers to small family homes. I came up with what I think
will be a great treehouse, but as always, there can be lots
of different successful solutions. So here's your challenge: can you come
up with your own architecture solution? What would your building look like? How would it meet the success
criteria and navigate the variables? Let us know! [Music]

Options: A. An engineer that designs and builds spaces, B. An engineer that designs and builds rockets, C. An engineer that designs and builds landscapes, D. An engineer that designs and builds cars, trucks, and moving vehicles
Correct Option: A

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In order to be successful, we need to isolate variables (elements or factors that are important or can change an idea). Why is it important that we look at the size of the tree and the weight of the treehouse?

Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: While Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X approached the Civil Rights Movement differently, they did have two things in common. What were they?
Options: A. They were both ministers and they both grew up in Nebraska., B. They were both ministers and they were both assassinated., C. They were both assassinated and they both found religion as adults., D. Both had sick mothers who died and fathers that were ministers.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: When was Malcolm X born? Options: A. May 19, 1910, B. May 19, 1925, C. May 19, 1930, D. May 19, 1940 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the name of Malcolm X's father? Options: A. Earl Little, B. Malcolm Little, C. Malcolm X, D. El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz Correct Option: None
Question 3: What group was often picking on Malcolm X's father? Options: A. African-American Civil Rights Activists, B. The Ku Klux Klan, C. Nation of Islam, D. Traditional Muslims Correct Option: None
Question 4: What event led to Malcolm X and his siblings being placed in foster care? Options: A. Death of Malcolm's father, B. Malcolm's mother becoming very sick, C. Malcolm getting into trouble, D. Malcolm discovering Islam Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the name of the religion that Malcolm X discovered in prison? Options: A. Islam, B. Christianity, C. Judaism, D. Buddhism Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the name of the organization that Malcolm X joined after discovering Islam? Options: A. Nation of Islam, B. African-American Civil Rights Activists, C. Traditional Muslims, D. Ku Klux Klan Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was Malcolm X's famous phrase when speaking against racism? Options: A. "By any means necessary", B. "You don't have to have a peaceful revolution", C. "Love thy neighbor", D. "Equality for all" Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the name that Malcolm X changed to after leaving the Nation of Islam? Options: A. El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz, B. Malcolm X, C. Malcolm Little, D. Earl Little Correct Option: None
Question 9: Where was Malcolm X assassinated? Options: A. Omaha, Nebraska, B. New York, New York, C. Washington, D.C., D. Los Angeles, California Correct Option: None
Question 10: On what date was Malcolm X assassinated? Options: A. February 20, 1965, B. February 21, 1965, C. February 22, 1965, D. February 23, 1965 Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs closely match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about the commonalities between Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X, while the generated MCQs focus on specific details about Malcolm X's life.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the topic of Malcolm X and the Civil Rights Movement, I would say that Question 7 is the closest match. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Malcom X's last name when he was born?
Options: A. Smart, B. X, C. Little, D. Johnson
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Options: A. They were being attacked by the Ku Klux Klan., B. His father received an important job elsewhere., C. His mother became ill and they moved to be closer to a hospital., D. They didn't have enough money to stay in Omaha.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The evil wizard MoldeVort 
has been trying to kill you for years, and today it looks like 
he’s going to succeed. But your friends are on their way, 
and if you can survive until they arrive, they should be able to help stop him. The evil wizard’s protective charms 
ward off every spell you know, so in an act of desperation 
you throw the only object in reach at him: Pythagoras’s cursed chessboard. It works, but with a catch. MoldeVort starts in one corner 
of the 5x5 board. You have a few minutes to choose 
four distinct positive whole numbers. MoldeVort gets to say one of them, 
and if you can pick a square on the board whose center is exactly 
that distance away, the curse will force him 
to move to that spot. Then he’ll have to choose 
any of the four numbers, and the process repeats until 
you can’t keep him inside the board with legal moves. Then he’ll break free of the spell 
and almost certainly kill you. What four numbers can you choose 
to keep MoldeVort trapped by your spell long enough for help to arrive? 
And what’s your strategy? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to keep MoldeVort 
where you want him. And one way to figure out how to do that is to play out the game 
as MoldeVort would: always trying to escape. You’re dealing with a relatively 
small board, so the numbers can’t be too big. Let’s start by trying 1, 2, 3, 4 
to see what happens. Moldevort could escape those numbers
in just three moves. By saying 2, then 3, he would force you to let him into one
of the middle points of the grid, and then a 4 would break him free. But that means you’ll need to allow
a number larger than 4, which is the distance from one end 
of a row to another. How is that even possible? Through diagonal moves. There are, in fact, points that are 
distance 5 from each other, which we know thanks 
to the Pythagorean Theorem. That states that the squares 
of the sides of a right triangle add up to the square of its hypotenuse. One of the most famous 
Pythagorean triples is 3, 4, 5, and that triangle is hiding all over 
your chessboard. So if MoldeVort was here, and he said 5,
you could move him to these spaces. There’s another insight that will help. The board is very symmetrical: 
If MoldeVort is in a corner, it doesn’t really matter 
to you which corner it is. So we can think of the corners 
as being functionally the same, and color them all blue. Similarly, the spaces neighboring 
the corners behave the same as each other, and we’ll make them red. Finally, the midpoints of the sides 
are a third type. So instead of having to develop a strategy for each of the 16 spaces 
on the outside of the board, we can reduce the problem to just three. Meanwhile, all the inside spaces 
are bad for us, because if MoldeVort ever reaches one, he’ll be able to say any number 
larger than 3 and go free. Orange spaces are trouble too, 
since any number except 1, 2, or 4 would take him to an inside space 
or off the board. So orange is out and you’ll need 
to keep him on blue and red. That means 2 is bad, since it could take MoldeVort 
to orange on the first turn. But the four other smallest numbers, 
1, 3, 4, and 5, might work. Let’s try them and see what happens. If MoldeVort says 1, you can make 
him go from blue to red or red to blue. And the same works if he says 3. Thanks to our diagonals, 
this is even true if he says 5. If he says 4, you can keep him 
on the color he’s already on by moving the length of a row or column. So these four numbers work! Even if your friends don’t get here 
right away, you’ll be able to keep 
the world’s most evil wizard contained for as long as you need.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are the dimensions of the cursed chessboard?
Options: A. 4 by 4, B. 5 by 5, C. 6 by 6, D. 8 by 8
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the goal of the main character in the story? Options: A. To defeat the evil wizard MoldeVort, B. To keep MoldeVort trapped on the chessboard, C. To find Pythagoras's cursed chessboard, D. To escape from the evil wizard MoldeVort Correct Option: None
Question 2: What type of theorem is used to find the distance between points on the chessboard? Options: A. Euclidean Theorem, B. Pythagorean Theorem, C. Geometric Theorem, D. Algebraic Theorem Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the famous Pythagorean triple mentioned in the story? Options: A. 2, 3, 4, B. 3, 4, 5, C. 5, 6, 7, D. 7, 8, 9 Correct Option: None
Question 4: What color is assigned to the corners of the chessboard? Options: A. Red, B. Blue, C. Green, D. Yellow Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the strategy for keeping MoldeVort trapped on the chessboard? Options: A. To move him to the center of the board, B. To keep him on the blue and red spaces, C. To allow him to escape to the orange spaces, D. To move him to the edge of the board Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the smallest number that MoldeVort can say to escape the spell? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: None
Question 7: What type of move can be used to reach a point that is distance 5 from another point on the chessboard? Options: A. Horizontal move, B. Vertical move, C. Diagonal move, D. Lateral move Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the consequence of MoldeVort reaching an inside space on the chessboard? Options: A. He will be trapped forever, B. He will be able to say any number larger than 3 and go free, C. He will be moved to the center of the board, D. He will be moved to the edge of the board Correct Option: None
Question 9: What color is assigned to the spaces neighboring the corners of the chessboard? Options: A. Blue, B. Red, C. Green, D. Yellow Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the strategy for choosing the four numbers to keep MoldeVort trapped on the chessboard? Options: A. To choose the largest numbers possible, B. To choose the smallest numbers possible, C. To choose numbers that will allow MoldeVort to escape, D. To choose numbers that will keep MoldeVort trapped on the blue and red spaces Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a method to identify the most similar generated MCQ.

To find the most similar generated MCQ, we need to analyze the content, options, and intent of each generated MCQ and compare it with the ground truth MCQ. Since none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ, we can look for MCQs that are related to the chessboard or its properties.

Question 7 is related to the chessboard, but it doesn't ask about the dimensions. Question 4 and Question 9 are also related to the chessboard, but they ask about the colors assigned to specific spaces.

Considering the intent and content of the generated MCQs, none of them match the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 7 is the most similar, but only because it's related to the chessboard, not because it matches the ground truth MCQ.

Index: None (or 7, if we consider the relation to the chessboard)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The evil wizard MoldeVort 
has been trying to kill you for years, and today it looks like 
he’s going to succeed. But your friends are on their way, 
and if you can survive until they arrive, they should be able to help stop him. The evil wizard’s protective charms 
ward off every spell you know, so in an act of desperation 
you throw the only object in reach at him: Pythagoras’s cursed chessboard. It works, but with a catch. MoldeVort starts in one corner 
of the 5x5 board. You have a few minutes to choose 
four distinct positive whole numbers. MoldeVort gets to say one of them, 
and if you can pick a square on the board whose center is exactly 
that distance away, the curse will force him 
to move to that spot. Then he’ll have to choose 
any of the four numbers, and the process repeats until 
you can’t keep him inside the board with legal moves. Then he’ll break free of the spell 
and almost certainly kill you. What four numbers can you choose 
to keep MoldeVort trapped by your spell long enough for help to arrive? 
And what’s your strategy? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to keep MoldeVort 
where you want him. And one way to figure out how to do that is to play out the game 
as MoldeVort would: always trying to escape. You’re dealing with a relatively 
small board, so the numbers can’t be too big. Let’s start by trying 1, 2, 3, 4 
to see what happens. Moldevort could escape those numbers
in just three moves. By saying 2, then 3, he would force you to let him into one
of the middle points of the grid, and then a 4 would break him free. But that means you’ll need to allow
a number larger than 4, which is the distance from one end 
of a row to another. How is that even possible? Through diagonal moves. There are, in fact, points that are 
distance 5 from each other, which we know thanks 
to the Pythagorean Theorem. That states that the squares 
of the sides of a right triangle add up to the square of its hypotenuse. One of the most famous 
Pythagorean triples is 3, 4, 5, and that triangle is hiding all over 
your chessboard. So if MoldeVort was here, and he said 5,
you could move him to these spaces. There’s another insight that will help. The board is very symmetrical: 
If MoldeVort is in a corner, it doesn’t really matter 
to you which corner it is. So we can think of the corners 
as being functionally the same, and color them all blue. Similarly, the spaces neighboring 
the corners behave the same as each other, and we’ll make them red. Finally, the midpoints of the sides 
are a third type. So instead of having to develop a strategy for each of the 16 spaces 
on the outside of the board, we can reduce the problem to just three. Meanwhile, all the inside spaces 
are bad for us, because if MoldeVort ever reaches one, he’ll be able to say any number 
larger than 3 and go free. Orange spaces are trouble too, 
since any number except 1, 2, or 4 would take him to an inside space 
or off the board. So orange is out and you’ll need 
to keep him on blue and red. That means 2 is bad, since it could take MoldeVort 
to orange on the first turn. But the four other smallest numbers, 
1, 3, 4, and 5, might work. Let’s try them and see what happens. If MoldeVort says 1, you can make 
him go from blue to red or red to blue. And the same works if he says 3. Thanks to our diagonals, 
this is even true if he says 5. If he says 4, you can keep him 
on the color he’s already on by moving the length of a row or column. So these four numbers work! Even if your friends don’t get here 
right away, you’ll be able to keep 
the world’s most evil wizard contained for as long as you need.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What do the numbers do?
Options: A. They specify the distance Moldevort must move., B. They specify the time Moldevort must spend in each spot., C. They specify how much money Moldevort must pay you., D. They don’t do anything.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The evil wizard MoldeVort 
has been trying to kill you for years, and today it looks like 
he’s going to succeed. But your friends are on their way, 
and if you can survive until they arrive, they should be able to help stop him. The evil wizard’s protective charms 
ward off every spell you know, so in an act of desperation 
you throw the only object in reach at him: Pythagoras’s cursed chessboard. It works, but with a catch. MoldeVort starts in one corner 
of the 5x5 board. You have a few minutes to choose 
four distinct positive whole numbers. MoldeVort gets to say one of them, 
and if you can pick a square on the board whose center is exactly 
that distance away, the curse will force him 
to move to that spot. Then he’ll have to choose 
any of the four numbers, and the process repeats until 
you can’t keep him inside the board with legal moves. Then he’ll break free of the spell 
and almost certainly kill you. What four numbers can you choose 
to keep MoldeVort trapped by your spell long enough for help to arrive? 
And what’s your strategy? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to keep MoldeVort 
where you want him. And one way to figure out how to do that is to play out the game

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
these word tales all make the same sound tick o tickle metal metal trav ul travel so how do you know which one to use l e is used 75 percent of the time so if you aren't sure try this one first if the word still doesn't look right try a l it's the next most common so when do you use el after the letters m n r v w and this is how you remember them most there's a camel with an m there's a tunnel there's a travel with a beanie excuse me what about these ones a l is coming after an m and an n not e l these are exceptions they have broken the rule but i can help you remember them signal my personal animal you

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. -le, B. -el, C. -al, D. -ly
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: What should you try first when unsure of which word to use, according to the speaker? Options: A. Try "a l" first, B. Try "e l" first, C. Look up the word in a dictionary, D. Ask a friend for help Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the second most common letter combination used in words, according to the speaker? Options: A. "a l", B. "e l", C. "i l", D. "o l" Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which letter combinations follow the rule of using "e l" after them, according to the speaker? Options: A. m, n, r, v, w, B. m, n, t, d, p, C. m, n, r, v, b, D. m, n, r, v, w Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is a way to remember the rule of using "e l" after the letters m, n, r, v, and w, according to the speaker? Options: A. A camel with an m, B. A tunnel with an n, C. A beanie with a travel, D. A signal with a personal animal Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which of the following words is an exception to the rule of using "e l" after the letters m, n, r, v, and w? Options: A. metal, B. travel, C. signal, D. personal Correct Option: None
Question 7: Which letter combination is used after the letters m and n, but is an exception to the rule, according to the speaker? Options: A. a l, B. e l, C. i l, D. o l Correct Option: None
Question 8: According to the speaker, what is a way to remember the exception of using "a l" after the letters m and n? Options: A. A camel with an m, B. A tunnel with an n, C. A beanie with a travel, D. A signal with a personal animal Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the purpose of the speaker's rule for using "e l" and "a l" in words, according to the transcript? Options: A. To confuse learners, B. To make learning easier, C. To test learners' knowledge, D. To entertain learners Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the speaker's tone and attitude towards helping learners, according to the transcript? Options: A. Sarcastic and dismissive, B. Friendly and helpful, C. Serious and strict, D. Boring and unenthusiastic Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3

**Transcript**:
these word tales all make the same sound tick o tickle metal metal trav ul travel so how do you know which one to use l e is used 75 percent of the time so if you aren't sure try this one first if the word still doesn't look right try a l it's the next most common so when do you use el after the letters m n r v w and this is how you remember them most there's a camel with an m there's a tunnel there's a travel with a beanie excuse me what about these ones a l is coming after an m and an n not e l these are exceptions they have broken the rule but i can help you remember them signal my personal animal you

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A new virus emerges 
and spreads like wildfire. In order to contain it, researchers must first collect data 
about who’s been infected. Two main viral testing techniques 
are critical: one tells you if you have the virus and the other shows 
if you’ve already had it. So, how exactly do these tests work? PCR, or polymerase chain 
reaction testing, targets the virus’s genetic material 
in the body and is used to diagnose someone 
who is currently infected. Yet, this genetic material may be present 
in such imperceptible amounts that actually detecting it is difficult. This is where PCR comes in: it’s widely used to amplify genetic 
information to large enough quantities that it can be readily observed. To develop a PCR test 
for a never-before-seen virus, researchers first sequence 
its genetic material, or genome, and identify regions that are unique 
to that specific virus. PCR then targets 
these particular segments. A PCR test begins by collecting a sample: this can be blood for hepatitis viruses, 
feces for poliovirus, and samples from the nose or throat 
for coronaviruses. The sample is taken 
to a central laboratory where PCR is performed to test 
for the presence of the virus’ genome. Genetic information can be encoded 
via DNA or RNA. HPV, for example, uses DNA, 
while SARS-CoV-2, the cause of COVID-19, uses RNA. Before running the PCR, 
the viral RNA— if present— must be reverse transcribed 
to make a strand of complementary DNA. Researchers then run the PCR. If the virus is present in the sample, 
its unique regions of genetic code will be identified by complementary 
primers and copied by enzymes. One strand of DNA becomes 
hundreds of millions, which are detected using probes marked
with fluorescent dye. If the PCR machine senses fluorescence, the sample has tested positive 
for the virus, meaning the individual is infected. Immunoassays, on the other hand, tap into the immune system’s 
memory of the virus, showing if someone has previously 
been infected. They work by targeting virus-specific
antibodies generated by the immune system during infection. These are specialized classes of proteins that identify and fight foreign 
substances, like viruses. Immunoassays may detect IgG antibodies, 
the most abundant class, and IgM antibodies, the type that’s first 
produced in response to a new infection. The presence of IgM antibodies suggests 
a recent infection, but since it can take the body over 
a week to produce a detectable amount, they’re unreliable in diagnosing 
current infections. Meanwhile, IgG antibodies circulate 
for an extended period after infection; their presence usually indicates 
that someone was exposed and recovered. Before the immunoassay, health professionals draw blood 
from an individual. This sample then comes into contact 
with a portion of the virus of interest. If the body has, in fact, been exposed 
to the virus in the past, the body’s virus-specific antibodies 
will bind to it during the test. This reaction produces a change in color, 
indicating that the sample tested positive and that the individual has been 
exposed to the virus. Immunoassays are especially important when it comes to retroactively 
diagnosing people who were infected but went untested. And there’s exciting potential for those
who have developed immunity to a virus: in some cases, their blood plasma 
could be used as treatment in people who are currently fighting it. PCR and immunoassays are always 
in the process of becoming more accurate and efficient. For example, innovations in PCR have led to the use
of self-contained testing devices that relay results within one hour. Digital PCR, which quantifies individual 
pieces of target DNA, shows promise in further
boosting accuracy. And although immunoassays are difficult 
to develop quickly, researchers in Singapore were able 
to create one for SARS-CoV-2 even before COVID-19 was declared 
a pandemic. These tests— along with the scientists 
who develop them and the health professionals 
who administer them— are absolutely essential. And when deployed early, 
they can save millions of lives.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do scientists even need to use polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing?
Options: A. In order to create complementary DNA sequences, B. In order to splice out genetic material segments, C. Due to the small amount of viral genetic material, D. Due to the number of people already infected
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary purpose of PCR testing in diagnosing viral infections? Options: A. To detect the presence of antibodies in the body, B. To target the virus's genetic material in the body, C. To measure the amount of virus present in the body, D. To identify the type of virus present in the body Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the process called when viral RNA is converted into a strand of complementary DNA before running the PCR? Options: A. Transcription, B. Reverse transcription, C. Translation, D. Mutation Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of antibodies suggests a recent infection, but can be unreliable in diagnosing current infections? Options: A. IgG, B. IgM, C. IgA, D. IgE Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the primary purpose of immunoassays in diagnosing viral infections? Options: A. To detect the presence of the virus's genetic material, B. To target the virus-specific antibodies generated by the immune system, C. To measure the amount of virus present in the body, D. To identify the type of virus present in the body Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the main difference between PCR and immunoassays in diagnosing viral infections? Options: A. PCR targets the virus's genetic material, while immunoassays target the virus-specific antibodies, B. PCR is used to diagnose current infections, while immunoassays are used to diagnose past infections, C. PCR is more accurate than immunoassays, D. Immunoassays are more efficient than PCR Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the purpose of using probes marked with fluorescent dye in PCR testing? Options: A. To detect the presence of the virus's genetic material, B. To measure the amount of virus present in the body, C. To identify the type of virus present in the body, D. To detect the presence of the virus's genetic material by detecting fluorescence Correct Option: None
Question 7: What type of PCR is used to quantify individual pieces of target DNA? Options: A. Standard PCR, B. Digital PCR, C. Real-time PCR, D. Quantitative PCR Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the advantage of using self-contained testing devices in PCR testing? Options: A. They are more accurate than standard PCR devices, B. They are more efficient than standard PCR devices, C. They can relay results within one hour, D. They are more expensive than standard PCR devices Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the purpose of using blood plasma from individuals who have developed immunity to a virus? Options: A. To treat individuals who are currently fighting the virus, B. To diagnose individuals who have been infected, C. To measure the amount of virus present in the body, D. To identify the type of virus present in the body Correct Option: None

They can be used to diagnose current infections, C. They can be used to diagnose past infections and provide a sense of closure for individuals who were infected but went untested, D. They can be used to identify the type of virus present in the body Correct Option: None
